channel.description: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast.

item.title: Mexico City Doomed By Its Geology To More Earthquakes
item.description: September 20, 2017 - The problem is that just to the west, a huge slab of the Earth's crust called the Cocos Plate is grinding relentlessly toward North America. And it's running under another slab to the north.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 20, 2017 - The problem is that just to the west, a huge slab of the Earth's crust called the Cocos Plate is grinding relentlessly toward North America. And it's running under another slab to the north. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/09/20/552428176/mexico-city-doomed-by-its-geology-to-more-earthquakes

item.title: Editing Embryo DNA Yields Clues About Early Human Development
item.description: September 20, 2017 - Researchers disabled a gene that they think helps determine which human embryos will develop normally. The technique they used is controversial because it could be used to change babies' DNA.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 20, 2017 - Researchers disabled a gene that they think helps determine which human embryos will develop normally. The technique they used is controversial because it could be used to change babies' DNA. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/09/20/551779921/editing-embryo-dna-yields-clues-about-early-human-development

item.title: Cassini's Spectacular Legacy â€” And Nod To The Future
item.description: September 20, 2017 - Following on Cassini's discoveries, NASA aims to probe Jupiter's Europa for potential life. With every new world we discover, we should look back at our own planet with awe, says Marcelo Gleiser.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 20, 2017 - Following on Cassini's discoveries, NASA aims to probe Jupiter's Europa for potential life. With every new world we discover, we should look back at our own planet with awe, says Marcelo Gleiser. http://www.npr.org/sections/13.7/2017/09/20/552076114/cassini-s-spectacular-legacy-and-a-nod-to-the-future

item.title: Bemoaning Budget Cuts, Health Care Navigators Say Feds Don't Get It
item.description: September 20, 2017 - The federal government has sharply cut funding to groups that help people enroll in health plans. But the groups say federal officials don't understand how much help and follow-up some people need.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 20, 2017 - The federal government has sharply cut funding to groups that help people enroll in health plans. But the groups say federal officials don't understand how much help and follow-up some people need. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/09/20/552094974/bemoaning-budget-cuts-health-care-navigators-say-feds-dont-get-it

item.title: Once Teased For Her Love Of Bugs, 8-Year-Old Co-Authors Scientific Paper
item.description: September 19, 2017 - Sophia Spencer was extremely fond of bugs, especially grasshoppers. Her peers didn't always appreciate her interest. Entomologists on Twitter, on the other hand, were huge fans of her passion.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 19, 2017 - Sophia Spencer was extremely fond of bugs, especially grasshoppers. Her peers didn't always appreciate her interest. Entomologists on Twitter, on the other hand, were huge fans of her passion. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/09/19/551876044/once-teased-for-her-love-of-bugs-8-year-old-co-authors-scientific-paper

item.title: A Girl's Love For Bugs Goes Viral
item.description:
September 19, 2017 - Canadian Sophia Spencer, 8, loves bugs. A tweet her mom sent out about that made headlines and led to a paper the girl co-authored in a science journal.
- http://www.npr.org/2017/09/19/552181920/a-girl-s-love-for-bugs-goes-viral
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: The Science And Art Of Mapping Animal Movements
item.description: September 19, 2017 - Technology allows mapping of wildlife movements with new precision â€” and a fresh approach to conservation â€” as evidenced by Where the Animals Go, released Tuesday in the U.S., says Barbara J. King.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

King. http://www.npr.org/sections/13.7/2017/09/19/552047632/the-science-and-art-of-mapping-animal-movements

item.title: Guess What's Showing Up In Our Shellfish? One Word: Plastics
item.description: September 19, 2017 - Scientists predict that plastic in the ocean will eventually outweigh the fish there. Where is it all coming from? And is it making our food unsafe? Researchers are trying to find the answers.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 19, 2017 - Scientists predict that plastic in the ocean will eventually outweigh the fish there. Where is it all coming from? And is it making our food unsafe? Researchers are trying to find the answers. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/09/19/551261222/guess-whats-showing-up-in-our-shellfish-one-word-plastics

item.title: We Shouldn't Stick Our Heads In The Sand, But We Do It Anyway
item.description:
September 18, 2017 - Ignorance is bliss, but knowledge is power...right?
- http://www.npr.org/2017/09/18/551901221/we-shouldn-t-stick-our-heads-in-the-sand-but-we-do-it-anyway

item.title: Fuel Shortages And The North Korean Economy, Explained
item.description: September 18, 2017 - A recent tweet by President Trump about long gas lines in North Korea reopens questions about what's going on in the country's opaque economy after several rounds of economic sanctions.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 18, 2017 - A recent tweet by President Trump about long gas lines in North Korea reopens questions about what's going on in the country's opaque economy after several rounds of economic sanctions. http://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2017/09/18/551756364/fuel-shortages-and-the-north-korean-economy-explained

item.title: Xanax Or Zoloft For Moms-To-Be: A New Study Assesses Safety
item.description: September 18, 2017 - Is it OK to take antidepressants or anxiety medicine during pregnancy? Recent research suggests women who need treatment can take these drugs. Doctors recommend the lowest effective dose.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 18, 2017 - Is it OK to take antidepressants or anxiety medicine during pregnancy? Recent research suggests women who need treatment can take these drugs. Doctors recommend the lowest effective dose. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/09/18/551020800/xanax-or-zoloft-for-moms-to-be-a-new-study-assesses-safety

item.title: Scientists Work To Grow Food In Space
item.description: September 17, 2017 - NPR's Lulu Garcia-Navarro talks with Gene Giacomelli of the University of Arizona about working with NASA to develop a kind of greenhouse where astronauts can grow crops while in space.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 17, 2017 - NPR's Lulu Garcia-Navarro talks with Gene Giacomelli of the University of Arizona about working with NASA to develop a kind of greenhouse where astronauts can grow crops while in space. http://www.npr.org/2017/09/17/551604539/scientists-work-to-grow-food-in-space

item.title: Researchers Look To Improve Weather Forecasting After Irma
item.description: September 17, 2017 - In coastal Georgia, Hurricane Irma caused far more flooding than expected. Researchers are looking at ways their mistakes there could improve future predictions elsewhere.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 17, 2017 - In coastal Georgia, Hurricane Irma caused far more flooding than expected. Researchers are looking at ways their mistakes there could improve future predictions elsewhere. http://www.npr.org/2017/09/17/551604516/researchers-look-to-improve-weather-forecasting-after-irma

item.title: Museums Engage In Informative Twitter Debate
item.description:
September 17, 2017 - Two museums in the U.K. argued on Twitter about who has better exhibits in a very informative fashion.
- http://www.npr.org/2017/09/17/551604465/museums-engage-in-informative-twitter-debate
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: Confusion Continues: The United States' Position On The Paris Climate Agreement
item.description: September 16, 2017 - The White House has reaffirmed its position on the climate pact "unless we can re-enter on terms that are more favorable to our country," after reports from AFP and the WSJ that the U.S. would stay.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 16, 2017 - The White House has reaffirmed its position on the climate pact "unless we can re-enter on terms that are more favorable to our country," after reports from AFP and the WSJ that the U.S. would stay. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/09/16/551551083/u-s-still-out-of-paris-climate-agreement-after-conflicting-reports
